Title: How do I make a simple combinatorial proof for the identity $\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{k}{n^k} \binom{n+1}{k+1}=n$?
Content:
Edit : So I have verified that my argument was correct, but I have just arrived to a different result. How do I give direct a combinatorial proof for this identity?
I want to prove combinatorially , $$\sum_{k=1}^{n} \frac{k}{n^k} \binom{n+1}{k+1}=n$$ My Attempt (didn't work) : Let's count the number of sequences of length $n+1$ : $(x_1,\ldots,x_{n+1})$ from a set of $n$ elements. For every $x_i$ , there are $n$ choices, so it is just simply $n^{n+1}$ We can also let $x_{k+1}$ be the first repeated element in our sequence. The first $k$ elements of the sequence can be chosen in $k!\binom{n}{k}$ ways (all distinct), and $x_{k+1}$ can be chosen in $k$ ways (choosing which of the first $k$ elements is repeated). The elements at the remaining $n-k$ positions can then be chosen in $n^{n-k}$ ways (no restriction at all). Multiplying these together and summing over $k$ , we get $$n^{n+1}=\sum_{k=0}^nk!\binom{n}{k}\cdot k\cdot n^{n-k} \tag1$$ Using $\binom{n}{k}=\frac{k+1}{n+1} \binom{n+1}{k+1}$ , $$n^{n+1}=\sum_{k=0}^{n} k!\cdot\frac{k+1}{n+1} \binom{n+1}{k+1}\cdot k\cdot\frac{n^n}{n^k} \tag2$$ $$n=\sum_{k=0}^{n} k!\cdot \frac{k+1}{n+1} \binom{n+1}{k+1} \cdot \frac{k}{n^k} \tag3$$ $$n=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{(k+1)!}{n+1} \binom{n+1}{k+1} \cdot \frac{k}{n^k} \tag4$$ So clearly I didn’t get the desired result (But it is infact correct).How do I give a direct combinatorial proof for the original identity?
AcceptedAnswer: Here's another solution, closer to what you were trying. We'll first prove $$(n+1)^{n+1}=\sum_{k=0}^n(k+1)\binom{n+1}{k+1}n^{n-k}$$ and from this we'll get the desired result. The combinatorial part will be proving the above identity, and transforming into what you want will be algebraic manipulation. Consider sequences $(x_1,\cdots,x_{n+1})$ such that exactly one of the $x_i$ 's equals $0$ and all the other $x_i$ 's are in $\{1,\cdots,n+1\}$ . We have $n+1$ ways to choose where to place the $0$ and then all the other positions have $n+1$ options, so we have $$(n+1)\cdot(n+1)^{n}=(n+1)^{n+1}$$ such sequences. On the other hand, we can count the number of $x_i$ 's that equal $1$ . We'll count how many sequences have $k\in\{0,\cdots,n\}$ ones. We can choose out of the $n+1$ positions, $k+1$ of them, and out of them choose one to be the $0$ and all the other ones to be $1$ . Then, out of the $n-k$ remaining positions, we can choose any number for each one out of $\{2,\cdots,n+1\}$ . So that gives us $\binom{n+1}{k+1}(k+1)n^{n-k}$ such ways. This proves the identity. Now, notice that \begin{align}(n+1)^{n+1}&=\sum_{k=0}^n(k+1)\binom{n+1}{k+1}n^{n-k}\\\\&=\sum_{k=0}^nk\binom{n+1}{k+1}n^{n-k}+\sum_{k=0}^n\binom{n+1}{k+1}n^{n-k}\\\\&=\sum_{k=1}^nk\binom{n+1}{k+1}n^{n-k}+\sum_{k=1}^{n+1}\binom{n+1}{k}n^{n+1-k}\\\\&=\sum_{k=1}^nk\binom{n+1}{k+1}n^{n-k}+(n+1)^{n+1}-n^{n+1}\\\\n^{n+1}&=\sum_{k=1}^nk\binom{n+1}{k+1}n^{n-k}\end{align} as we wanted. Notice that this arrives at the same identity as the other comment by other means, although I hadn't seen the other solution, so this shows that you can also arrived via this approach more similar to what you were thinking
